awd_abstract_narration:
AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Active DNA Assembly of Aperiodic Structures
PIs: N.C. Seeman, N. Jonoska

The science of computing and information processing is rapidly proliferating within established disciplines that at first glance appear unrelated.  Examples include
biochemistry and biology through the areas of bioinformatics and algorithmic molecular assembly, or physics, through quantum computing.  Current top-down photolithographic methods of electronic component construction are likely to encounter severe barriers as miniaturization requires features at very small sizes.  An alternative approach to such construction is programmable bottom-up assembly on the molecular scale.  The most popular basis for bottom-up assembly is DNA self-assembly, because DNA contains information through which assembly can be controlled in a variety of ways. This approach has been explored by a variety of laboratories in recent years, but was pioneered by the PI Seeman's laboratory roughly thirty years ago. Robust DNA motifs can be self-assembled into objects, lattices and devices, using the information content inherent in the DNA molecules (or their analogs) themselves.  Notable milestones include the self-assembly of DNA polyhedra, the self-assembly of 2D DNA periodic lattices, the self-assembly of  high-resolution 3D DNA crystals, the development of clocked and autonomous cascade-like DNA walkers, the development of DNA origami, and the construction of 1D and 2D algorithmic assemblies.  

This project aims to combine several of these developments to produce robust aperiodic structures that will enable nano-scale construction of computational machinery.  The goal of the project is to introduce a new paradigm in the self-assembly of nano-scale devices by DNA self-assembly:  active (rather than passive) recursion-based assembly of aperiodic structures. The project will incorporate elements of DNA walkers into DNA origami-based tiles as signals that guide hierarchical active assembly of aperiodic arrays. 

The proposed hierarchical algorithmic assembly would be the first demonstration of recursion in molecular self-assembly that can be seen as a physical incarnation of programmed recursion. It is known that self-similar and fractal-like structures have advantages in material design, heat exchange and information processing, e.g., the very significant advances obtained by miniature fractal-like antennas.  Consequently, the possibilities for self-similar arrangements at the nano-scale can be expected to advance further the design of materials and electronics, while decreasing the costs involved in their construction.

Project Outcomes

 

Most of us are aware that the DNA double helix contains the genetic information for all organisms and is of central importance for the understanding of heredity, the diagnosis of hereditary disease and in the establishment of forensic data.  It is less widely known that DNA information can be encrypted in the molecule by synthetic chemistry for our purposes, rather than for nature's.  'Our purposes' involve getting DNA to perform computations and to build smart materials.  Our key experimental outcome in this project is a major advance in this direction. .  When we design and synthesize our own DNA sequences, we can make branched molecules, rather than the linear helix backbones with which we are familiar.  Thus, with the proper programming of their sequences, it is possible to get numerous DNA strands to come together to form tile-like arrangements. It is possible to have these tiles tailed by short single-strands of DNA called 'sticky ends'.  These sticky ends turn the tiles into 'Lego blocks', which can bind to each other to form larger constructs. Molecules associate with each other according to chemical rules and in the case of DNA, the sticky ends can act as labels, so that a particular sticky end can be programmed to bind to another sticky end, thereby linking two tiles.  Thus, putting a group of tiles into a given solution can result in the formation of a particular arrangement of them with individual associations programmed in 1, 2 or 3 dimensions. This  has been known since the end of the last century.                                                          

 

In order to make patterns that are less simple, or to use the tiles not just as building blocks, but as logic gates, leading to complex or fractal patterns, there are chemical issues that need to be overcome.  For example, we may not want tile 4 to bind to tile 5 until tile 3 has bound to tile 4.  If tiles 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 are put into solution, nothing prevents binding of tiles 4 and 5; after all, they are both in each other's vicinity all the time, once dissolved.  We have designed a system that makes a particular binding event dependent on previous events.  Thus, if tile 4 binds to tile 5, tile 3 must have bound to tile 4. We have devised an activation mechanism based on the notion that binding on one side of a tile activates its other side.  This works very successfully in our hands, so that we can now build cascades of associations that can be used in conditional situations, where associations are a consequence of molecular logic, not merely simple self-assembly. Theoretically, we have proved that indeed this mechanism can be used to assemble the molecules in a recursive, self-similar manner, building up a fractal-like structures. The mechanism was also a base for new theoretical tile self-assembly models that have full computational power with dynamical changes of the assembled structures through controlled detachments.

 

The project was inherently interdisciplinary providing training in both experimental and theoretical aspects of the project to all trainees. The trainees include a postdoc at NYU two PhD students at USF and three undergraduates at NYU and USF respectively. A workshop on topological and discrete models in molecular biology was organized at USF and a book on this topic was published. The book was used as a textbook in a graduate course at USF.
